Greg




	
		Posted 
21 May 2004 08:10 PM




Ten years ago, I had a harmless but large tumour removed from my cheek and neck that was from my Parotid Gland.

That's all gone of course. But in the last 3-4 weeks I have noticed a lump on the lower part of my gum. It does not hurt and it is pink like my gum. It's fairly firm and it does not hurt when I press it (unless I press hard).

I have also noticed my saliva production has increased, but I am think that may be down to anxiety.

This lump is about 2-3 cm long and protrudes about 5 mm which makes my lower cheek bulge slightly.

What could it be and should I trouble my doctor with it (I sort of know the answer to that already)?

Thank you - Greg


	 	
	Posts: 7 | Location: Leicester | Registered: 21 May 2004	





	

PaulineT




	
		Posted 
23 May 2004 02:48 AM




Hi Greg
Go the docs on Monday - you know what to do so stop procrastinating...... As a former sufferer of this area you can I think be demanding about getting a ENT consultant appointment within 2 weeks. My GP phoned the hospital as I left his room and got me an appointment just 9 days later.

I am concerned about the size of your lump and about the excess saliva you mention. For about 9 months prior to the diagnosis I started to wake up with a a drop or two of saliva at the corner of my mouth. It had never happened before ever.

At first it was once about every 3 weeks then it increased to two weeks then to weekly and by the time of my op it happened every other day or so.

I have come across one other person who told me they had this as a symptom. It stopped after surgery, but happened about once just before radiotherapy and then stopped again. 

You must check this out. Let us know. I want it to be harmless for you. We all have delayed at some point not quite believing we could be one of the statistics.

Good luck.


	 	
	Posts: 323 | Location: Worcestershire, England, UK | Registered: 10 June 2003

PLEASE DO GO GREG,, THERE IS NO SENSE IN DELAYING OR PUTTING THIS OFF ANOTHER DAY, GO FIND OUT WHAT IS WHAT,,THEN GO FROM THERE,, PLEASE KEEP US INFORMED,,,WE HAVE TO STICK TOGETHER THRU THIS,,,,BE STRONG,, BE BRAVE,,GO, GO, GO , ALWAYS VICKI LYNN

Thank you Pauline and Vickie.

Yes, I had already talked myself into going on Monday to my doctors, even if it is nothing to worry about, I of course do need to know. You are both so right about not waiting anymore.

I will update very soon and thank you all for your encouragement.

Greg

Greg

25 May 2004 01:58 AM




Saw the doctor this morning and he was concerned enough to urgently refer me to an Oral Surgeon. I should hear from that department very soon.

At least the ball is rolling to deal with this problem. It may be benign after all this worry anyway.

Sounding rather cowardly, I am frightened more when I read about everyone's cases here on this forum. I am amazed at how brave you all are.

Greg

		Posted 
25 May 2004 02:15 AM




Greg  -  don't be fooled.

Once diagnosed I'm pretty sure most of us were terrified.  That feeling doesn't go away.

What's cowardly about being frightened, there'd be something wrong with you if you weren't worried/concerned/frightened.

Whatever the news please keep us posted

Greg we are not brave just realistic can't get away from the fact we got it so live with it. As Pikeman says we are all frightened when we get diagnosed. As pikeman also says that feeling doesn't go away, but we are all in this togeather so we help each other. If you read my diary about when I was diagnosed you will see you are not any more frightened than I was. As you say the outcome from you apointment might not be as bad as you think.
Keep us informed

      Modernising Rural Delivery newsletters - current and 
        archived 

      The newsletter allows us to keep in touch with those interested in the 
        programme, give an overview of significant milestones as we progress through 
        the MRD Programme and to look in more depth at some of the projects that 
        form part of MRD.

      Archived newsletters

       
      
Welcome to August’s edition

      The newsletter is available to download. 
         
        [54 KB] 

      Contents

      Sustainable Development Investment

        Review of Rural Services

        Programme People

        EFRA Committee Inquiry - the potential of England's Rural 
        Economy 

      With only one full month until the formal establishment of Natural England 
        and the Commission for Rural Communities, hopefully everyone’s refreshed 
        from their Summer breaks as attention turns to all that has to be achieved 
        in the coming month.

      As well as vesting Natural England and the Commission for Rural Communities, 
        1 October will also see the RDAs (see interview in this edition with Steve 
        Heaton from the Northwest Development Agency) take on management of the 
        delivery of the EU rural socio-economic funding, previously delivered 
        by the RDS. These are the key milestones for the MRD programme and reaching 
        them will be a huge achievement for all staff and partners involved, not 
        least those continuing to deliver vital services to customers while preparing 
        for the organisational changes. But we're not there yet. There is lots 
        more still to do in the last few weeks, particularly to ensure that all 
        our staff know what they will be doing and that they and our stakeholders 
        have all the information they need. Please bear with us. In just over 
        a month's time, we should have organisations in place that can carry on 
        the good work of the founding bodies and deliver major improvements for 
        rural communities and the natural environment.

      This month’s edition also brings updates on Sustainable Development 
        Investment, the Review of Rural Services and a forthcoming EFRA Committee 
        Inquiry into England’s Rural Economy.

      Esmee Wilcox 

        Communications Team Leader, MRD Programme

      Sustainable Development Investment 

      Defra and the Regional Development Agencies (RDAs) have produced a new 
        publication urging investment in sustainable development. 

        Smart Productivity (http://www.sustainable-development.gov.uk/publications/documents/smart-productivity1.pdf 
        ) argues that this type of investment will generate long term economic 
        growth, environmental sustainability and social inclusion. 

      The report highlights areas where RDAs have current projects which support 
        the UK Sustainable Development Strategy:

      	Enterprise: Growing the wind power sector in eastern England to bring 
          both economic and environmental benefits for the UK.
	Competition: From new uses for recycled glass in London to energy 
          saving support in the North West.
	Investment: Supporting wood chip fuel production in Northumberland 
          and new regeneration in Bristol city centre.
	Innovation: Developing technology to end the energy drain of electrical 
          devices in Yorkshire.
	Skills: Making better use of resources in the West Midlands to develop 
          skills in the economically inactive. 


      For more information on Sustainable Development: http://www.sustainable-development.gov.uk/what/latestnews.htm#ln10072006

      For a copy of Defra/RDAs latest newsletter: http://www.frameworks-city.ltd.uk/r2c_06/index.htm

      Review of Rural Services

      Defra published its Rural Services Review on 31st July 2006. The review 
        is intended for everyone working in, and with an interest in, rural areas. 
        It sets out the standards for 11 core services for the rural public, including 
        education, health and social care, provision of broadband, transport, 
        postal services and emergency services.

      Following feedback from readers, the 2006 edition is much more about 
        ‘real people and real issues’ and as a consequence the publication 
        is intended to be more balanced and informative. The ‘Did you know’ 
        section has been expanded with the inclusion of more targeted signposting 
        around all the key case studies. The topics are more reflective of the 
        concerns facing rural communities today and describe some innovative ways 
        communities have addressed these issues. The aim is to inspire more people 
        to take those first steps to understand and address the needs of their 
        own communities.

      A copy of the report (www.defra.gov.uk/rural/pdfs/services/rural-services-review-2006.pdf) 
        can be found on Defra’s Rural Services internet pages

        (www.defra.gov.uk/rural/services)

      Programme People

      This 
        month we have been talking to Steve Heaton from the Northwest Development 
        Agency (NWDA).

      Steve has been spearheading the development and implementation of the 
        Agency’s rural affairs policy and delivery in the North West for 
        three years. His main responsibility has been to implement the NWDA’s 
        £100 million Rural Renaissance Programme, in order to make a major 
        contribution to rural development within England’s Northwest.

      i) How have you and your team been anticipating taking on the new socio-economic 
        work in October?

      The work has a number of components from our perspective. There is a 
        significant amount of internal activity with a cross agency team involved. 
        That team is looking at all the business process implications of taking 
        on the socio-economic work.

      In parallel to that the rural team has been leading on the development 
        of the new programme for the region. NWDA has a strong sub-regional emphasis 
        and we have asked the sub-regions to work out what the key priorities 
        are for them. Each has to do this within the framework of the measures 
        available under the regulation, the steer from the strategy consultation 
        and the priorities in the Regional Rural Delivery Framework and the Regional 
        Economic Strategy. These various sources give a pretty clear steer to 
        sub-regions as they identify their own priorities. We have a significant 
        interest in delivery using the Leader methodology and expect that to form 
        a major part of delivery of Axes 1 and 3. 

      ii) How do you see devolution to the regions impacting on rural development?

      It provides an important opportunity for the region and, in the case 
        of NWDA, the sub-regions to establish priorities. The development of Regional 
        Rural Delivery Frameworks has brought partners together and helped generate 
        a better shared understanding of each others’ priorities. That shared 
        understanding is of enormous benefit when rural development is being planned 
        and implemented. 

      iii) What differences will your customers notice over the coming year?

      Our customers are likely to be sub-regional partners who will be undertaking 
        delivery on our behalf. We hope to use existing structures wherever possible 
        and this should provide a high degree of continuity for final beneficiaries.

      iv) What’s your top priority in the region at the moment?

      Rural Renaissance, a £100m investment programme by NWDA, is in 
        its fourth year of a five year delivery plan. Inevitably the early years 
        of such a programme focus on capacity building and development work. Pressing 
        ahead with agreed delivery is the key objective over the remainder of 
        the programme. The bulk of the investment is being made in the final two 
        years of the programme.

      v) When you think about your role in the RDA since you joined in 2003, 
        what stands out the most?

      The strengthening of the devolution agenda. NWDA was at the forefront 
        of developing a region wide rural strategy which was, in many ways, a 
        forerunner of Regional Rural Delivery Frameworks. I think that the NWDA 
        model influenced both the Haskins report and Rural Strategy 2004 and gave 
        confidence that devolution of strategy and delivery to regional and sub-regional 
        level could work. I think this has represented a very significant change 
        of emphasis.

      vi) What’s been the most challenging part of the MRD reforms to 
        date? What opportunities have you gained either now or that you see coming 
        in the future?

      Getting partners to understand that the changes were not simply about 
        a different organisation doing what its predecessor had done. Looking 
        ahead, I think that how we achieve, in a practical and meaningful way, 
        integration of delivery across the three delivery axes of the Rural Development 
        Regulation is going to be a challenge.

      The major opportunities from MRD are better alignment of funding, a co-ordinated 
        strategic approach across all pillars of sustainable development and a 
        reduction in duplication. We have also been able to build on some of the 
        piloting work of the Countryside Agency and expand some activities across 
        the region. Wheels2Work is a good example.

      vii) What’s your experience so far, and hopes for, partnership 
        working with Natural England and the Commission for Rural Communities?

      The regional devolution agenda has been embraced by many partners but 
        how Natural England is able to embrace it will be important. I hope that 
        there will be significant regional autonomy so that public sector interventions 
        can be focused to achieve best results. 

      Working with the CRC has been limited thus far given that it has a small 
        regional presence. It is however a productive relationship and we are 
        hoping to be able to provide accommodation for a member of CRC staff in 
        one of our offices. On a practical basis this would help ensure a continuing 
        close relationship. 

      EFRA Committee Inquiry – the potential of England’s Rural 
        Economy

      EFRA, the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee, has decided 
        to undertake a new inquiry – The Potential of England’s Rural 
        Economy. The aim is to highlight the potential of England's rural economy: 
        what could be achieved and the barriers to achieving it. The Committee 
        is going to build on recent parliamentary scrutiny of the MRD reforms 
        – in 2004 looking at the Rural Strategy, and in 2005 the Natural 
        Environment and Rural Communities Bill. 

      In particular, the inquiry will consider: 

      - Defra's objectives for economic development in rural areas, including 
        the relevant Public Service Agreement (PSA) targets and funding.

      - Regional Development Agencies’ (RDAs) role in unlocking the economic 
        potential of rural areas, and Defra's relationship with RDAs.

      - Agricultural and non-agricultural providers of rural employment and 
        possible barriers to their further development.

      - Ensuring rural proofing arrangements are effective in rural aspects 
        of economic development and are properly reflected in national and regional 
        policy.

      - The role of Natural England and the CRC.

      See Press Release at http://www.parliament.uk/parliamentary_committees/environment__food_and_rural_affairs/efra_pn61_060727.cfm

	Medical Research Council announces 29 novel projects to give £5 million boost to brain sciences.	
	The Medical Research Council today (Monday 9 February 2004) announced the award of 29 grants worth £5m as part of its initiative to strengthen UK brain sciences research and build foundations for future work to help tackle major mental health problems.

The innovative projects cover a wide variety of scientific approaches to address major disorders and diseases such as depression, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, Huntington’s, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.  

The awards range from basic studies of genetics, biological markers and mechanisms of disease, utilising new imaging techniques or better exploitation of existing technology to creating new or enhanced packages of care for mental health and future development of clinical trials.

The awards are made as a result of the first round of the MRC’s call for proposals for brain sciences research launched in the Summer of 2003.  The call followed two themes: ‘Trial Platforms’ to pave the way for rigorous evaluation using clinical trials and ‘Pathfinders’ designed to build knowledge and capacity for future research.  

A total of £ 2.23m was awarded for 11 Trial Platforms and £2.82m for 18 Pathfinder grants.  MRC was particularly keen to attract bright scientists at early stages of their careers for the Pathfinder grants and eight of these projects will be led by such researchers.

The successful awards include*:
 
•Testing of new imaging technology to help surgeons target more precisely the areas in the brain to treat Parkinson’s in order to improve the outcome of neurosurgery

•Exploring brain inflammation as a predictor for Alzheimer’s 

•Study of changes in the white brain matter in sufferers of bi-polar (manic depressive) disorder in order to explore the genetic basis of  to look for genetic clues to the illness

•Study of gene FOXP2 implicated in developmental learning disorders such autism, dyslexia and speech and language impairment.

•Vitamin treatment to reduce the amino acid homocysteine (a newly discovered risk factor) in the blood of Alzheimer’s patients 

•Understanding causes of depression in pregnant women and the long-term health effects for mother and child.

•Understanding how anti-depressants work in the body with the aim of improving therapies and targeted treatment 

Professor Nancy Rothwell, Chair of the MRC Neurosciences and Mental Health Board who chaired the Pathfinder panel said: 

“We had an excellent response to this call and the standard of application was very high.  The pathfinder grants are all dynamic, internationally competitive and will advance our understanding of mental illness.  In the longer term they offer hope of new diagnosis, prevention and treatment.”

Dr  David Armstrong, Chair of the MRC Health Services and  Public Health Research Board  who chaired the Trial Platform panel said:”

“Overall, two thirds of all the grants awarded are for clinical research.   Well-designed clinical trials are important if we are to effectively assess the healthcare being provided to the population.  Some of these platforms create potential for large-scale trials in the future, but many could have an immediate impact on care and the ways in which it is provided for patients and their families.”

Professor Colin Blakemore, Chief Executive of the MRC said: “This package of awards is a really exciting boost for brain research which will address some of the most common problems affecting people in the UK today.

“We have a good mix of experienced researchers and those at the start of their careers.   Developing scientists’ careers is one of my priorities for the MRC and this should help them fulfil what the panel saw as their outstanding potential as leading researchers for the future.  

“The applications we received were also so cost-effective that we’ve been able to support a third more projects than we anticipated at the outset.”

ENDS

For more information please call the MRC press office on 020 7 637 6011

Notes to Editors:

* These grants have been highlighted to show range and diversity and do not reflect any other status attached to them

You are here: Home / Consumer information / Your rights when shopping from home / Internet auctions












Internet auctions - before bidding



Here are some specific things to look out for.

Check out the website

You will need to register on the site before you can buy or sell. Make sure you read all the information before agreeing anything.

What protection does the site offer if a transaction goes wrong? Remember the site provider can refuse to accept responsibility if a trade goes wrong because of a trader's action.

Many sites do provide users with limited compensation in some instances and also access to dispute resolution schemes but be clear what is being offered.

Check out the seller or buyer

Most auction sites operate a feedback system which allows you to see comments by other users who have traded with that person. Check the person's rating and read the comments. If you see bad comments consider carefully whether or not to trade. Check out where the trader is based, how easy would it be to get your money back if things went wrong?

Check out the item you are buying:

	ensure the description of the item is adequate 

	don't be afraid to ask questions before bidding if you are unsure of something, an honest seller will be happy to clarify 

	do some research and work out what would be a fair price for the item 

	set yourself a maximum bid and stick to it


Make sure you know:

	how much is the postage 

	will the item be insured 

	is it being sent from overseas 

	are your credit card details kept secure 

	what form of payment will the seller accept.


Payments

Paying by credit card can in some circumstances offer additional protection. So does payment by escrow service, where a trusted third party holds the money until the goods are received.

More competition means lower unemployment

Release date: 18 Apr 2006

Opening product markets up to competition has helped to reduce unemployment in many European countries, according to new research from the Institute for Fiscal Studies.


 The study by Rachel Griffith, Rupert Harrison and Gareth Macartney, which was presented at the Royal Economic Society’s 2006 Annual Conference at the University of Nottingham, also finds that increased competition has raised workers’ real wages. 	Abstract:	In 1999, Tanzania enacted a basic new land law in the form of the Land Act and the Village Land Act. The latter lays out the legal framework and procedures for most of Tanzania’s rural land to henceforth be governed through a community-based land tenure management system. This devolves authority over land administration, land management and dispute resolution to the community level. This paper aims to provide a very simple but comprehensive explanation of the Village Land Act, which came into effect in May 2001. It includes a list of questions and answers about the new law, which were originally for Tanzanian District Councils as base material upon which they developed simple material aids and guidelines for villagers.

text:
IMesh Toolkit - Software Products

	
	 

 


	

	
	
	
	 	











         

 

	
	
	
	
	
	
 


	

 

The IMesh Toolkit



 


[ Work In Hand > Technology Review > Products ]




 


Harvest





(Based on contributions by Martin Hamilton, accessible in this 
report.)

 	Provider	Harvest was originally developed by the Internet
Research Taskforce Group on Resource Discovery (IRTF-RD) as part
of an ARPA-funded project (Bowman et al 1994). The final official
Harvest release (1.4pl2) forms the basis for current open source
development.

 Download http://www.tardis.ed.ac.uk/harvest/


 Community support: harvest-develop@tardis.ed.ac.uk mailing list
and comp.infosystems.harvest Usenet group
		Licensing requirements: Open source software
distributed under the terms of the GNU General Public
License.
	Purpose	Originally intended to be a generalised resource
discovery system built in a modularised fashion, designed as an
open-ended system using network protocols, programming APIs and a
standard metadata format (SOIF).
	Approach	A Gatherer component performs indexing of
arbitrary content, using the Essence system from the University
of Arizona (included in the package). Metadata records (in SOIF
format) are produced by summarisers; the metadata records are
made available by the Gatherer component; a Broker component
periodically fetches SOIF records from Gatherers and indexes
them. The Broker is searched either using the Harvest Broker
protocol, or by plugging in search engines. The package tries to
implement the modular design by reusing readily available
software (such as existing indexers e.g. glimpse, the Essence
system, existing HTTP servers), and Harvest is essentially the
plumbing to connect these components together over a
network.
	Platform and
requirements	Http server, Perl, C compiler. Runs on any modern
Unix-like system.
	Components and their
technology	
	Server	The Harvest Broker component serves this
role.
	Database	
	Search
tools/clients	User interacts via HTTP. Search is performed via
a web form. A Perl CGI script (nph-search) speaks the Harvest
Broker protocol to the Broker and returns HTML to the end
user.
	API	
	Metadata Formats	Only the SOIF metadata format (originally
developed for Harvest) is supported.
	Extras/Other
features	Very limited web-based administration features
are provided, e.g. one can initiate a gathering operation.
		A new version of Harvest is written entirely in
Perl.
		See review
in the Renardus report for additional comments.

STATUTORY INSTRUMENTS



2004 No. 2891


ANIMALS, ENGLAND


ANIMAL HEALTH


The Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) (England) Order 2004

	 	
Made	6th November 2004	 
	 	
Coming into force	1st December 2004	 




The Secretary of State, in exercise of her powers under sections 1, 7 and 23(f) and (g) of the Animal Health Act 1981[1] makes the following Order:



Title, commencement and application

    

1.
 - (1) This Order may be cited as the Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) (England) Order 2004 and comes into force on 1st December 2004.


    (2) This Order applies to England only.



Amendments to the Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) Order 1978

    

2.
 - (1) The Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) Order 1978[2] is amended in relation to England in accordance with the following provisions of this article.


    (2) In paragraph (2) of article 6 of the 1978 Order (which specifies the date until which disinfectants subject to transitional provisions remain approved), for "31st August 2003" substitute "28th February 2005".


    (3) For Schedule 1 to the 1978 Order (which lists approved disinfectants) substitute Schedule 1 to this Order.


    (4) For Schedule 2 to the 1978 Order (which lists disinfectants subject to transitional provisions) substitute Schedule 2 to this Order.



Revocations

    

3.
The following Orders are revoked - 




(a) Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) (England) Order 2003[3];


(b) Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) (England) Order 2001[4];


(c) Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) (England) Order 2000[5];


(d) Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) (Amendment) Order 1999[6], to the extent that it relates to England.




Ben Bradshaw

Parliamentary Under Secretary of State, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs



6th November 2004

EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Order)


This Order, which applies to England only, amends the Diseases of Animals (Approved Disinfectants) Order 1978, revokes earlier amendment Orders and comes into force on 1st December 2004. It substitutes for Schedules 1 and 2 to the 1978 Order the Schedules set out in this Order. Schedule 1 lists disinfectants approved by the Secretary of State and Schedule 2 lists disinfectants which, although no longer approved, may continue to be used as approved disinfectants until 28th February 2005.


This Order was notified in draft to the European Commission in accordance with Directive 98/34/EC, as amended by Directive 98/48/EC.


A regulatory impact assessment has not been prepared.

Does early education have long-lasting effects?

Release date: 09 Dec 2005
 Download press release  [39 KB]
A new paper published today (9 December 2005) in Fiscal Studies, evaluates the effects of early education on a cohort of British children born in 1958. In contrast to most available studies, the paper assesses the longer term impact on these children, considering how early education has affected their cognitive and social skills whilst at school, and their educational attainment and labour market outcomes into adulthood.

Quality Standards including Partners in Innovation

The NYA’s Quality Standards Team takes an interest in all things to do with standards, targets, performance indicators, training and qualifications, quality assurance, professional development and innovation in Youth Work … linking particularly with the Department for Education and Skill’s policy document Transforming Youth Work: Resourcing Excellent Youth Services.
There are well established areas of work within the Quality Standards Team's remit, such as:
	the professional validation of Higher Education courses and endorsement of Youth Support Worker Qualifications through the Education and Training Standards Committee that reviews and inspects the universities and colleges of higher education that offer youth work programmes, and monitors vocational qualifications for youth support workers.
	Partners in Innovation (PIN) 

There are aspects of the new agenda such as:
Workforce Development
Dealing with recruitment, retention, training and the continuous professional development of youth workers. Following on from the recommendations of the Transforming Youth Work Warwick Conference in 2002 the Workforce Development Implementation Group worked on the next phase. Its report was welcomed by Margaret Hodge, Minister for Children and Young People.  
You can download a copy of the full report  and the executive summary    
The NYA has produced guidelines and self-assessment framework to help organisations providing youth work services to create a workforce development policy and seek NYA accreditation.  An accredited workforce development policy is now one of the recognised characteristics of a good quality youth service, in line with the Government's Resourcing Excellent Youth Services agenda.  Guidelines for Development and Accrediting a Workforce Development Policy in a Youth Work Organisation are available from the NYA Quality Standards Team priced at £30 + VAT.  For further information contact Ann Wilson or Diane Evans - NYA Quality Standards Team.  
Refining the Youth Work Standards and Performance Indicators
The NYA icontinues to work with DfES in sharpening the standards and targets in REYS, making sure they match up with each other and improving their practical usage.  More information is available on:
	Credit Where It s Due Benchmark and FAQs

Youth Services Quality Mark
REYS stated the Government wanted to see a kitemark developed which would give the seal of approval for Youth Services.  The NYA together with its Quality Action Group is working up proposals with pilots in each of the 9 regions developing the Quality Mark.  View the list of QAG members.
Visit the Quality Mark website.
FAQs about Quality Mark
We've tried to give some answers to many of the questions people frequently ask us to do with youth work training, qualifications and professional development on the frequently asked questions part of The NYA site. 
Members and contact details of the Quality Standards Team are set out on The NYA staff list - go to About the NYA

title: The Methodist Church of Great Britain
text:
The Methodist Church of Great Britain

	The Methodist Church of Great Britain
	 



	 Faith, Ministry & Church: Vice President John Bell addresses Conference






The new Vice President of Conference 2005/6, 
John Bell, is a retired
business executive from the Chester and Stoke 
District. He was
educated at grammar schools in Sunderland and 
Newcastle, later
studying Economics at Manchester University 
and Industrial Management
at the University of Leeds. He is married to 
Joan and has two grown-up
children, Alison and Martin. John has a 
special interest in the role
of faith in the workplace, and in the 
selection and training of people
for ministry.






This morning John addressed delegates and 
guests at the Sunday morning
worship service, welcoming a diverse assembly 
of people and inviting
them to reflect on faith, ministry and church 
from their own
perspectives. He spoke of those who had 
profoundly influenced and
challenged him on his own faith journey, 
encouraging those present to
do the same.






Speaking on the diversity that comes with 
faith, John commented that
"Perhaps, the broader our base, the stronger 
we may become. Let us
hold this in our minds when we consider the 
Conference report
Pilgrimage of Faith, reflecting our shared 
journey on human sexuality.
No, we haven't arrived; the journey is not 
straightforward; maybe we
don't even know the destination. But let us 
continue to journey,
safely, together.






"Our faith, with its amalgam of belief and 
unbelief, our confidence in
God this day, even if we would have difficulty 
articulating these
things, are a gathering of all that has gone 
before in our lives,
perhaps shredded, honed and glued together 
again through the years.
Like the two on the road to Emmaus, as we 
journey and wrestle, we will
glimpse Jesus, the risen Lord."






This diversity of faith is carried into the 
ministry of the church in
all its variety. John challenged ordained 
ministers to have the
courage to follow their hopes for the 
Methodist Church in the 21st
Century, and spoke of the need to recognise 
the value of lay ministry;
"Yes, we may engage in the work of the 
gathered church, but we have
enormous opportunity to exercise our Christian 
ministry where we work
or otherwise commit and spend our time 
(whether in parenting, in
retirement, in community service, in many 
other situations). What a
wonderful opportunity we have! And yet, so 
neglected in the
ecclesiastical pecking order. In my time with 
the Connexional
Candidates Committee, I often asked candidates 
about their call to
ordained ministry – it seemed a fair question –
 and was most dismayed
by the sincerely offered answers that amounted 
to 'I want to give
myself full-time to serving God. I can't do 
that in a secular job:'
oh, no? Where did you develop this taste for 
luxury? Of course I knew
what they meant, but it seemed to betray a 
narrow view of mission
possibilities."






Moving to the final of the service's themes, 
he said, "What is surely
beyond doubt is that 'the church' is the 
hardest bit. People say 'it's
not just about numbers:' no, it isn't. If we 
reflect on the Old
Testament idea of the remnant of Israel, maybe 
we are the Christian
remnant today in whom God has put his trust. 
But we cannot be content
that God expects nothing of us: Jesus' great 
commission in Matthew 28
to make disciples of all nations is direct 
enough. It's neither
complacency nor panic, but faith and vision 
with a strong dose of
honesty and realism that are needed."






John believes that being part of the Church 
involves four key
challenges for each and every member; 
upholding the faithful through
pastoral support, finding fresh ways or being 
and doing church,
working in partnership with those of other 
denominations and learning
from the confidence and success of our partner 
churches in other
continents.






Finally John called for the Church to be open 
to new insights in the
search for and pilgrimage with God, for which 
being open to the person
and work of Jesus and the inspirational 
challenge of discipleship is
essential.

art06 agenda debate
This event is now sold out



art06 agenda debate in association with BBC Radio 3's Night Waves 



Where: The Harris Museum and Art Gallery, Preston 



When: Thursday 8 June; 3.30pm-5pm



Arts, Faith and Freedom

We live in a country of many cultures. Concern has grown over the way that faith is represented. In such a context, can the artist still claim total freedom of expression? Artists of all backgrounds and descriptions have recently found themselves colliding with religious and racial sensitivities. A Sikh playwright was attacked for her work by other Sikhs. A satirical opera featuring Christ was barracked by Christians. Internationally, the pattern repeats itself as nations increasingly lose homogeneity.  

 

The panel explores whether it is enough to cite artistic freedom as the over-riding good. Surely rights must be balanced with responsibilities?  Does the right to give offence outweigh the right not to be offended? And in the final alliance, might we need to find a new process and dialogue so that sections that currently and dangerously feel excluded can be part of a public debate?  

 

This timely art06 debate is in association with Night Waves, BBC Radio 3's daily arts and ideas programme.  The discussion will be broadcast on Radio 3 on Monday 12 June at 9.30pm.

 

The panel is chaired by Paul Allen and includes the prominent playwright, David Edgar.

	Rehabilitation of Offenders - Act 1974 - guidance notes

Under the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974, you do not need to provide details about previous convictions which are "spent", unless the post for which you are applying specifies that a criminal record check is included in the recruitment process. 
A conviction becomes spent after a certain length of time which changes depending upon the sentence and your age at the time of conviction. 
Examples are:
	Sentence
	Age 18 or over When convicted
	Under 18
When convicted

	6 months to 2.5 years Imprisonment
	10 years
	5 years

	Less than 6 months Imprisonment
	7 years 
	3 years

	Borstal Training
	7 years
	7 years

	A Fine or Community Service Order
	5 years 
	2 years

	Probation Order, Conditional Discharge order, or Bound Over
	1 year (or when order expires)
	1 year (or when order expires)

	An Absolute Discharge
	6 months
	6 months

	Detention Centres
	3 years 
	3 years



Note: If a person is sentenced to more than 2.5 years in prison, their conviction can never become 'spent'.

Any information given will be treated as confidential and used only in connection with this application.

An offer of employment may be withdrawn or dismissal may result if previous convictions for 'unspent' criminal offences are not disclosed.

If you have any doubts about whether you have to declare a previous conviction, you should contact your local Probation Office or the Citizens Advice Bureau, or your Solicitor.

	Some time ago, here in Scotland, volunteers were asked to provide DNA samples in order to determine the extent of Viking descent. the results were interesting. For example one third of men in Shetland are of Viking decent,; the other two thirds are of Pictish or Celtic descent. A bit awkward as most Shetlanders would rather not be part of Scotland.





So it would seem to be possible to determine where one's ancestors came from using DNA evidence.





Now the introduction to the Book of Mormon is clear. The Lamanites were descended from a group which emigrated from Jerusalem and they are the principal ancestors of the American Indians.





If this has no doctrinal or scriptural justification, why does the introduction to The Book of Mormon contain the information? If the information is false, how much else of the introduction is false?





The question is quite simple. If the American Indians are descended from the Lamanites who originated in Jerusalem, is there any DNA evidence at all to support this?





Margaret

	Hi Margaret,





	Margaret wrote:
	Some time ago, here in Scotland, volunteers were asked to provide DNA samples in order to determine the extent of Viking descent. the results were interesting. For example one third of men in Shetland are of Viking decent,; the other two thirds are of Pictish or Celtic descent. A bit awkward as most Shetlanders would rather not be part of Scotland.







I can do something similar.  If I send in a blood sample and a hundred bucks, they can tell me if my family came to the US from Scotland via the group that migrated to Ireland in the 1700's; or if I came from Scotland via the group that stayed and fought for the English king.  DNA can do some great things.





	Quote:
	So it would seem to be possible to determine where one's ancestors came from using DNA evidence.







DNA can give us a remarkable amount of information about a very limited specific topics, yes.





	Quote:
	Now the introduction to the Book of Mormon is clear. The Lamanites were descended from a group which emigrated from Jerusalem and they are the principal ancestors of the American Indians.





...





The question is quite simple. If the American Indians are descended from the Lamanites who originated in Jerusalem, is there any DNA evidence at all to support this?










Here's the relevant portion of the intro to the BoM:





The record gives an account of two great civilizations. One came from Jerusalem in 600 B.C., and afterward separated into two nations, known as the Nephites and the Lamanites. ... After thousands of years, all were destroyed except the Lamanites, and they are the principal ancestors of the American Indians.





The problem is twofold:


1) We don't know much of anything about the genetics of the original people who came from Jerusalem.  Although some genetic lines can be traced (like the Cohen line), there isn't any such thing as "Hebrew DNA".





2) The definition of what it means to be a Lamanite changes over the hundreds of years from 600 BC to the end of the BoM.  It doesn't just mean genetics and parentage.  It's became a political affiliation, religious affiliation, and a choice.





(Cue David Letterman "top 10" music)





Top 7 Ways You know you're a Lamanite.  Be warned, that #1 is a doozie!





7) You rejected the gospel as personally given by Jesus Christ


(4 Nephi 1:38 ) And it came to pass that they who rejected the gospel were called Lamanites, and Lemuelites, and Ishmaelites 





6) You are a Nephite that decides to call yourself a Lamanite around 84 A.D.


(4 Nephi 1:20) "And he kept it eighty and four years, and there was still peace in the land, save it were a small part of the people who had revolted from the church and taken upon them the name of Lamanites; therefore there began to be Lamanites again in the land."





5) You are a direct descendant of Laman (Regardless of which "side" you are on)


(Alma 55:4-5)"And now it came to pass that when Moroni had said these words, he caused that a search should be made among his men, that perhaps he might find a man who was a descendant of Laman among them. And it came to pass that they found one, whose name was Laman; and he was one of the servants of the king who was murdered by Amalickiah."





4) You are a descendant of Zoram


(Alma 54:23-24) "I am Ammoron, and a descendant of Zoram, whom your fathers pressed and brought out of Jerusalem. And behold now, I am a bold Lamanite;..."


(Alma 43:4) "For behold, it came to pass that the Zoramites became Lamanites;"





3) You are a Nephite Defector


(Moroni 9:24) "And if it so be that they perish, we know that many of our brethren have deserted over unto the Lamanites, and many more will also desert over unto them; wherefore, write somewhat a few things, if thou art spared and I shall perish and not see thee; but I trust that I may see thee soon; for I have sacred records that I would deliver up unto thee."





2) You are not a Lamanite, but become one due to your certain "dissentions"


(D&C 10:48 ) "Yea, and this was their faith—that my gospel, which I gave unto them that they might preach in their days, might come unto their brethren the Lamanites, and also all that had become Lamanites because of their dissensions."





And the number one way to know you're a Lamanite:





1) According to a prophecy given around 73 B.C., you are a Lamanite if you wake up in the Americas one day around 400 A.D. to discover you are still breathing:


(Alma 45:14) "But whosoever remaineth, and is not destroyed in that great and dreadful day, shall be numbered among the Lamanites, and shall become like unto them, all, save it be a few who shall be called the disciples of the Lord; and them shall the Lamanites pursue even until they shall become extinct. And now, because of iniquity, this prophecy shall be fulfilled."











Margaret, DNA science is fascinating stuff.  But it doesn't prove or disprove the BoM - there just isn't any way to set up a proper test.  If you're interested, I really do recommend the links I posted a few posts ago.  Here they are again:

	http://farms.byu.edu/publications/dna.php?selection=dna&cat=dna 





I'd recommend Matt Roper's Nephi's Neighbors: Book of Mormon Peoples and Pre-Columbian Populations, Sorenson's The Problematic Role of DNA Testing in Unraveling Human History, and especially David McClellan's Detecting Lehi's Genetic Signature: Possible, Probable, or Not?.

Back to the introduction to the B0fM.





The line of descent is clear. A group of people migrated from the Middle East. It seperated into two nations, the Nephites and the Lamanites. Eventually only the latter survived and they are the anscestors of the American Indians. It doesn't say that the Lamanites weren't really Lamanites, only half, or partial or sort of Lamanites, somehow different from the group which came from Jerusalem.





However, even if a Lamanite was a Nephite who became or deserted to the Lamanites, or a descendant of Zoram, he would still be able to trace his anscestry back to the people who came from Jerusalem and his DNA would indicate an origin in the Middle East or at least have charecteristics in common with other ME inhabitants.

The big glaring assumption you are making is that the Americas were empty of all people except for Lehi and gang.  The BoM never makes that claim, and the archaeological record would seem to indicate that other people were in various parts of north, central, and south america at various times before, during, and after the BoM takes place.   





The BoM is silent about how these groups interacted.  It's possible they intermarried and mixed genes.  It's possible that whatever genetic markers Lehi brought with him didn't survive past 300 a.d.

	HSR,





Thanks for your post.





The introduction states that the Lamanites were the PRINCIPAL ancestors of the American Indians. This does not suggest much in the way of inter-marriage with other races which may have been there at the time.





You say that the Book of Mormon is silent on the subject of other groups of people that Lehi and his descendants may have come across. Yet it goes into detail about the animals, the types of plants and the metals they found there. It seems odd then that nothing is said about any other inhabitants that may have been there also, particularly if inter-marriage was involved. The Bible records vividly the many stresses and tensions which resulted when God's people formed marriage relationships with the heathen tribes that shared their land. Would the people of the Book of Mormon not have had similar problems? The B of M claims to be a history of the former inhabitants of the continent. For inter-marriage to have taken place on a scale sufficient for the Jewish migrants to have lost their genetic markers by 300AD (a mere 900 years since their arrival in 600BC) there must have been a serious breakdown in the structure of their society and for this to have happened without it being considered significant enough to warrant any mention in the Book of Mormon seems incredible.











Did the early leaders believe that the American Indians were mainly of Lamanite descent? It would appear so from their statements. Joseph Smith sent delegations to preach to "the Lamanites", he spoke of "the borders of the Lamanites" and while he did not say that all the American Indians of his day were Lamanites, the impression he gave was that they were principally of Lamanite descent.





Brigham Young also considered the American Indians to be Lamanites and of Jewish descent.  





In "Discourses of Brigham Young", compiled be John Widtsoe, pages 122 and 123, he is quoted as saying,





"There is a curse on these aborigines of our country who roam the plains, and are so wild that you cannot tame them. They are of the House of Israel: they once had the Gospel delivered to them, they had the oracles of truth: Jesus came and administered to them after his resurrection, and they received and delighted in the Gospel until the fourth generation when they turned away and became so wicked that God cursed them with this dark and benighted and loathsome condition."





He did not say "they used to be", nor did he suggest that their genetic inheritance had become so watered down that no-one could say any longer where in fact they came from, he said "they ARE of the House of Israel." So where is the DNA evidence to support this?





Spencer Kimball took a gentler view of the Lamanites. From "The Teachings of Spencer W. Kimball", p596 I quote,  --





"You Polynesians of the Pacific are called Samoan or Maori, Tahitian or Hawaiian, according to your islands. There are probably 60 million of you on the two continents and on the Pacific Islands, all related by blood ties. The Lord calls you Lamanites, a name which has a pleasant ring, for many of the grandest people ever to live upon the earth were so called. In a limited sense, the name signifies the descendants of Laman and Lemuel, sons of your first American parent Lehi; but you undoubtedly possess also the blood of the other sons, Sam, Nephi and Jacob. And you likely have some Jewish blood from Mulek, son of Zedekiah, king of Judah. The name Lamanite distinguishes you from other peoples. It is not a name of derision or embarrassment, but one of which to be proud."





I assume therefore, that there is DNA evidence to support this teaching that the inhabitants of the Pacific Islands are of Semitic origin. 





Margaret

	Hi Margaret,





It seems from your post that you continue to not avail yourself of the links I posted.  I urge you, for a third time, to do so.  They really, really do explore this fascinating issue more broadly and more deeply than I'm able to.





	Margaret wrote:
	The introduction states that the Lamanites were the PRINCIPAL ancestors of the American Indians. This does not suggest much in the way of inter-marriage with other races which may have been there at the time.







Correct.  The BoM is mostly silent on the presence of others, and possible intermingling.





	Quote:
	It seems odd then that nothing is said about any other inhabitants that may have been there also, particularly if inter-marriage was involved. The Bible records vividly the many stresses and tensions which resulted when God's people formed marriage relationships with the heathen tribes that shared their land. Would the people of the Book of Mormon not have had similar problems?







Keep in mind that the BoM, as we have it today, is not the total record left by those people.  The Bible's scope is also a lot more comprehensive across both centuries and peoples.  To draw a rough analogy, the Bible is like the complete history of Europe for 15 centuries, the BoM is like the history of the Welsh people from 1300-1400.   Much different scope.





	Quote:
	 For inter-marriage to have taken place on a scale sufficient for the Jewish migrants to have lost their genetic markers by 300AD (a mere 900 years since their arrival in 600BC) there must have been a serious breakdown in the structure of their society and for this to have happened without it being considered significant enough to warrant any mention in the Book of Mormon seems incredible.







Really, it's not.  Archaology paints a fairly believable picture of possibly several million inhabitants living in the Americas when Lehi arrived in 600 BC.  Compare several million against Lehi's small group (we're not really told how many, but maybe 30 or 40 people total?).  It's really not that hard to believe that the genetics got lost in the soup.





Again, the link above contains an essay giving people a quick "genetics 101" lesson that helps you understand this.





	Quote:
	Did the early leaders believe that the American Indians were mainly of Lamanite descent? 







Short answer - yes.  And we still do.  The word "principal ancestor" still applies.  Again, "Lamanite descent" can mean many different things.  It's possible that every person alive when Columbus arrived was related in some way to Lehi, and it's quite probable that any or all genetic markers have been lost.





	Quote:
	I assume therefore, that there is DNA evidence to support this teaching that the inhabitants of the Pacific Islands are of Semitic origin. 










You seem quite hesitant to abandon this question, even though I keep pointing out to you that it's moot.  I suggest again that you go read the articles I mentioned above, and come back if you think they don't address your issue to your satisfaction.

	HSR,





I suppose I am holding on to the DNA issue - though I suspect not as tightly as you would had the evidence shown any link between the Semitic Peoples and the American Indians.





You say that when the migrant group which numbered only 40-60 people reached the New World they found a very much larger population, of possibly several millions, already there. I would suggest at this stage that even several millions, from the tip of Alaska to the bottom end of South America would have been spread rather thinly and it would have been quite possible for this band of people to have continued for quite a long time without being assimilated into a larger group. 





That's just a thought, but when I also consider that migrant people tend to stick together, especially when they find themselves in an alien land and that God's  people in the Old World were not supposed to inter-marry anyway, I am skeptical. If they had been assimilated to the degree you suggest - that they "lost" their DNA, they would also have lost their cultural and ultimately spiritual identity. Yet the Book of Mormon records these people as creating great civilizations and being unique enough to be considered the "Other Sheep" when it recounts Jesus appearing to them.





I have had a look round various sites, admittedly only a small portion of the many available,  and I only found one scientist who mentioned the "genetic soup" theory and that was only a passing references. None of 


the others did. These are scientists who are working in the field of genetic research, and they include Mormons, and their conclusions seem to be that there is no link between the American Indians and the Jewish Peoples. If there was a plausable explanation (ie genetic soup") for the absence of DNA they would have referred to it and not considered this absence such a serious problem for the credibility of the Book of Mormon.





The problem I find with the FARMS link you gave is that, as far as I understand, this research foundation was set up and funded  by the Mormon Church in order to provide evidence for the authenticity of the Book of Mormon. This in itself does not invalidate its research but as it is not independant, its findings must be viewed with a degree of caution. Rather than honestly looking at the evidence and seeing where it leads, however uncomfortable that might be , there is the danger of shaping the evidence to fit a predetermined conclusion.





If, for example, schools were provided with educational materials fronted by a dentist, who claimed that sugar was not so damaging to children's teeth and health as previously thought, you might, and I hope you would, wonder who was paying for it. You would not be surprised then to find out the money was coming from a sugar company. 





Neither of us knows enough about this subject to be able to properly evaluate all the research findings. All we can do is read widely and come to as honest a conclusion as possible.





So where are we? The Lamanites, from the far north of Canada, down through South America and across the Pacific, have no identifiable Jewish blood in them. This is in spite of many, many assurances by Mormon prophets and apostles, that they were, and are, "of royal blood," "the children of Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph and Lehi." Now it seems they could have come from anywhere - except we now know for sure, as was always suspected, that they came from Asia and there is no evidence at all to suggest a Middle East input.





Some of the writers I've come across have stated that the amount of research which has been done, in this area as well as others, ie geography, linguistics etc, has undermined the authority of the Book of Mormon as a historical document and thus of Joseph Smith as a prophet. It has been suggested that one way forward for the Mormon Church would be to gradually phase out its teaching that the Book of Mormon is a factual history, and replace it, again gradually, with the idea that it is only an expression of a spiritual experience and not to be taken literally. 





Any thoughts?





Margaret

Again, please tell me what "Jewish blood" looks like.  Does it come from the Ashkenazim, the largest proportion of the identifiable Jewish people existing today? I'll quote a bit from one of my FARMS articles:





In order to understand what Israel meant anciently in terms of kinship relations, it is necessary to review the history and development of that people as described in the biblical account. Abraham is the first person to be called a "Hebrew" in the Bible (Genesis 14:13), though his grandson Jacob, who lived in Syria for a time, is termed a "Syrian" (Deuteronomy 26:5). The Bible gives us the names of Abraham's patrilineal male ancestors, but we know nothing about the origin of his mother or his wife Sarah. This poses a problem for a researcher hoping to trace the Abrahamic genetic heritage using mtDNA.





In addition to Sarah's son, Isaac, Abraham had sons by two other wives: an Egyptian named Hagar, who bore Ishmael (Genesis 16:1, 3; 21:9; 25:12); and a woman of unknown origin named Keturah, who bore six sons (Genesis 25:1–4). Besides his own children and immediate family, Abraham's house included men and women servants and people he had converted to his faith (Genesis 12:5; Abraham 2:15). Among these were his chief steward, Eliezer (Genesis 15:2), and 318 "trained servants, born in his own house," who could be mustered for battle (Genesis 14:14). All of these, according to the custom of the time, would have been considered "Hebrews," though they may have had no biological relationship to Abraham. This presents a second problem for those who hope to use the Bible as documentation of genetic connections.





Abraham's son Ishmael married an Egyptian woman (Genesis 21:21), while Isaac married his cousin Rebekah. Isaac's son Esau had two Hittite wives (Genesis 26:34) and another who was a daughter of Ishmael (Genesis 28:8-9). Esau's brother, Jacob, who came to be known as Israel, fathered twelve sons and one daughter by four wives (Genesis 29:28–35; 30:1–24; 35:15–19). Each of Jacob's children would have carried the mtDNA of his or her mother. While two of these wives, Leah and Rachel, were Jacob's cousins, the Bible tells us nothing of the origins and background of the other two, Zilpah and Bilhah.





Likewise, little is known of the women who married the sons of Jacob, though we know that Joseph married an Egyptian, Asenath, who bore him Manasseh and Ephraim (Genesis 41:45, 50–52).8 Joseph's half-brother Judah had three sons by a Canaanite wife named Shuah and twin sons by Tamar, whose ancestry is unknown (Genesis 38:2–30). Of the half-Canaanite sons, only one (Shelah) lived long enough to have posterity, but his mtDNA would be unlike that of his half-brothers, Pharez and Zarah, unless their mothers were sisters (Genesis 46:12; Numbers 26:19–21). From Pharez descended Salmon, who married the Canaanite woman Rahab, who had been spared with her father's household during the Israelite destruction of the city of Jericho in Joshua's day. Their son was Boaz, who married the Moabitess Ruth, who became the great-grandmother of King David and, consequently, of all the kings of Judah and of Jesus Christ himself (Ruth 4:18–22; Matthew 1:2–16). While most of the kings of Judah from whom Christ is descended married women of the same tribe or of other Israelite tribes, this is not true of all of them. For example, Rehoboam, son of Solomon, was born of a woman named Naamah, who was an Ammonitess (1�Kings 14:21, 31; 2 �Chronicles 12:13). Genesis 40:10 informs us that Simeon had a Canaanite wife, but nothing is said of the other wives of Jacob's sons or their origins, although it seems likely that they also married outside Abraham's kin group. The children and grandchildren of Jacob who are mentioned in the biblical account number seventy, but this does not include daughters and granddaughters. Although nothing is specifically said on the matter, it is not unreasonable to assume that Jacob's people included servants and their families as well.9 One thing, however, seems certain: all of Jacob's grandchildren inherited their mtDNA from their mothers, who were likely non-Israelite.





We know very little about Israelite marriage practices in Egypt during the four-hundred-year sojourn there; however, there is some indication that intermarriage with non-Israelite peoples was not uncommon (see, for example, Leviticus 24:10). Moses married a Midianitess (Exodus 2:21). When the Israelites left Egypt, it is said that a "mixed multitude" went with them (Exodus 12:38; Numbers 11:4).10 Whatever its size, the exodus group included many who were not descended from Jacob's original family.11 We have no details about the ancestry of these other people, but we know from Leviticus 24:10 that at least one of the men who fled into the wilderness with Moses had an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father.

Headline Comparisons
	Central government current receipts in November were 4.9% higher than in the same month last year.
This month’s Pre-Budget Report forecast for 2004–05 implies an increase over last year’s levels of 7.2% for the year as a whole and of 7.5% for the period from November 2004 to March 2005. Although the latest month’s data appears disappointing in isolation, revisions to previous months have lifted the increase over the year to date from 6.3% in last month’s release to 6.8%. This brings it closer to the Pre-Budget Report forecast.

	Central government current spending in November were 9.2% higher than in the same month last year.
This month’s Pre-Budget Report forecast for 2004–05 implies an increase over last year’s levels of 5.2% for the year as a whole and of 2.8% for the period from November 2004 to March 2005. The latest figures show an increase over last year’s levels of 7.3% for the year to date.

	 Public sector net investment in November was £1.4bn, or 17.8% higher than in the same month last year.
This month’s Pre-Budget Report forecast for 2004–05 implies an increase of 55.8% for the year as a whole and an increase of 91.3% for the period from November 2004 to March 2005. The latest figures show an increase over last year’s levels of 11.6% for the year to date.

      Wild bird populations across the UK are nearly ten percent higher than they were ten years ago, according to a major survey published today. 

      The government's indicator for wild bird populations 2004 shows that there have been large increases in some upland and

      	
	A greenfinch 


      wetland birds such as buzzard and little ringed plover, while kingfisher and peregrine falcon have recovered from previously low numbers. 

      Warmer winters and more environment-friendly farming may be helping many scarce birds, while species including the chiffchaff, greenfinch and whitethroat are also showing strong signs of recovery. 

      Defra is committed to reversing the long-term decline in the number of farmland birds by 2020. New agri-environment schemes, backed by £150 million a year, include a range of measures that will have widespread benefits for farmland birds. 

      The overall farmland birds index has been stable since 1994 although it shows a small decline between 2003 and 2004 . As well as whitethroat and greenfinch, there are encouraging signs of recovery for tree sparrow. 

      Minister for climate change and environment, Elliot Morley said: 

      “Bird populations are a good gauge of the general state of our wildlife and countryside. This government is committed to supporting and working with farmers and others to restore and enhance the habitats and conditions necessary for our precious birds to survive and thrive. 

      "The exact reasons for changes in various populations are largely unknown and often very complex. We have several research projects on the go, but they may not provide easy or short-term answers. 

      “However, more and more farmers are joining new agri-environment schemes - now covering more than one million hectares in England alone - which can secure many more safe breeding and feeding grounds for farmland birds and other wildlife. “ 

      The wild bird population indicator is one of 20 UK framework indicators under the government's Sustainable Development Strategy. The indicator covers 111 species of breeding birds native to the UK, but excludes introduced and rare species. 

      Further information

		These guidelines are a tool to enable you to develop good practice for the delivery of library and learning resource services for higher education provision in a further education institution.
	



	
	 
They are also a guide to establishing quality procedures within further education institutions and between those higher education institutions with whom they work. 

Because of the diversity of provision of higher education within further education, the guidance cannot cover every possible scenario that may arise. Therefore it is essential that you increase your understanding by: 


	Being visible and pro-active within your institution 

	Being involved in the wider professional world, which will provide you with a broad base on which to learn from, and share knowledge with, colleagues in other institutions 

	Being aware of developments within the library and information sector by reading the professional and educational press and regularly checking relevant websites, such as, DfES, HEFC, Ofsted, ALI, LSC, QAA, CILIP, MLA 


As a library and learning resource manager you can use these guidelines to inform the development of your services and to illustrate within your institution examples of good practice that should be adopted. 

There are differences in the provision of higher education in further education institutions in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland because there are significant differences in the delivery of education. These guidelines have been designed to be as generic as possible.

title: Anaerobic Digestion
text:
Anaerobic Digestion 
November 2004 
Briefing 
Anaerobic digestion 
 
Introduction 
Following the implementation in the UK of the EU Landfill Directive, much of the 
biodegradable waste stream which would previously have been sent to landfill has to be 
dealt with by other means. With strong public opposition from local communities to 
incineration, local authorities are increasingly looking for other means to tackle the UK’s 
growing waste problem. One such technique, explained in this briefing, is the process of 
anaerobic digestion (AD). 
 Anaerobic digestion 
AD is a biological process naturally occurring in environments with little or no oxygen. For a 
long time AD has been used by the farming community to process cattle slurry into a soil 
enhancer. However, with better capturing of by-products, the process is now being promoted 
by some sections of the waste industry as a technology suitable for treating biodegradable 
municipal waste (BMW). 
AD can be used to treat all types of biodegradable waste, including food waste. It is also 
used to stabilise mixed waste after the removal of recyclable materials, but the resulting solid 
and liquid digestates will be of lower quality and may not be suitable for use as soil 
enhancers. 
Anaerobic Digestion– how it works 
AD breaks down organic materials within an in-vessel or controlled environment. This is 
usually an airtight container, known as a digester. The AD process releases by-products, 
these are: 
• Biogas, which is made up of around 60% methane (CH4) and 40% carbon dioxide 
(CO2). This can be burnt to generate heat and/or electricity. 
• Bio liquid or liquor digestate, which can be used, if of suitable quality, to improve soils 
as a conditioner or fertiliser.  
• Fibre digestate, which can also be used, if of suitable quality, as a compost to apply to 
soil. 
Characteristically you can divide the AD process into two stages.  
Stage one – Inside the digester 
This stage is in two phases. The first, the acidification phase (acetogenesis) is when micro-
organisms release enzymes that convert organic compounds into fatty acids, hydrogen and 
acetic acid.  
The second phase known as methanogenesis is when methane and carbon dioxide are 
produced from the organic acids.  
During both phases there should be tight controls on the pH level to keep it between 5.5-8.5 
1
and the temperature to stay within 30-60°C, these conditions maximise the digestion rates. 
Stage two– Treating the by-products. 
In the second stage, the biogas is scrubbed so it is fit to be used in the generation of 
electricity, while the liquid and solid digestates are used as soil enhancers or disposed of 
according to their quality. The suitability of the digestates depends on a number of factors 
such as its level of contamination and how biodegradable the incoming waste stream or 
feedstock is. Garden and kitchen waste separated at the first point of disposal, i.e. at the 
home or kerbside (source separated) provides the best feedstock.   
 
 
 2Anaerobic digestion 
 
Potential advantages of AD 
1. AD can process a range of different types of BMW.  
• It can complement composting systems, catching biodegradable waste that can’t 
be processed through windrow composting - such as cooked kitchen waste and 
animal by-products.  
• It can be used to stabilise waste, after mechanical separation as part of an MBT-
type plant (see box 1), before it goes to landfill. 
2. AD produces useful by-products, which can be easily captured. 
• The  biogas produced can be combusted when the AD plant is used with a 
combined heat and power plant (CHP), providing electricity (which can power the AD 
process or be added to the national grid) and heat for homes.  
• Methane can be further refined to produce fuel related products such as 
2
methanol, but AD’s role in producing biofuels needs further researching.   
  
• Fibre and liquid digestates can provide soil improvers and fertilisers. This may 
become increasingly important as the UK Government looks to improve soil 
3
conditions and the EU Soils Directive develops. There is also some evidence that 
4
the digestates may suppress normal soil pathogen and parasite levels.  
• The digestates from AD which go to landfill are stabilised and compacted, 
5
reducing the amount of methane and leachate produced as well as odour and dust. 
AD takes under 35 days to stabilise waste, where as in landfill, biological waste may 
6
emit methane and leachate for over 35 years.  
3. Where data exists, compared to incineration, landfill and pyrolysis and gasification, AD 
7
produces the least net air and solid emissions .  
4. Plants can be small and low rise so may be situated in towns, reducing haulage 
distances and associated traffic pollutants. 
Potential disadvantages of AD 
1. Local authorities may see AD as a substitute for source separating materials for 
recycling and composting. Source separation is preferable to mechanical separation 
8
as it produces a better sorted waste fraction and encourages people to overcome 
9
the “throw away culture.”  
2. If the feedstock is poor and AD cannot process the waste into soil enhancers, further 
techniques such as composting may be needed, resulting in increased expenditure. 
3. If AD does not completely biodegrade the waste, the digestate may not meet with 
Government standards, so will not help local authorities to meet their Landfill 
10
Allowance Trading Scheme targets.  
4. AD plants create a lot of waste water. This will contain a high nitrite load and will 
 3Anaerobic digestion 
need further processing before it can be disposed into sewage systems - although 
11
some water may be re-circulated during AD, particularly when the feedstock is dry. 
5. AD plants may have negative local impacts on the environment such as odour, dust 
and pollutants associated with burning methane. There are few examples of sizable 
plants in the UK, so environmental and health impacts have not been widely 
observed.  
 
BOX 1. Mechanical and Biological Treatment (MBT)  
MBT is a technology that treats mixed residual waste. It mechanically extracts metals, glass, 
plastics and contaminants such as batteries still left in the waste stream. This maximises the 
diversion of recyclables after source separation. The other part of MBT, the biological stage, 
is the point at which biodegradables are decomposed to reduce and stabilise the biologically 
active materials. Some MBT systems may propose AD for this biological stage, capturing the 
methane to provide energy for the plant. The residue can then be landfilled. 
For more information read Friends of the Earth’s briefing at  
http://www.foe.co.uk/resource/briefings/mchnical_biolo_treatmnt.pdf 
 
The impact on climate change and human health 
Climate Change  
Waste disposal contributes to climate change, for example through the release of methane 
from landfill or the burning of fossil fuel derived plastics. Sending untreated waste to landfill 
and incineration are the worst options for climate change – according to research by the 
 12
Community Recycling Network. 
Biogas composing of methane and carbon dioxide is the main climate change concern from 
the AD process. Studies show that the CO2 produced from AD has a shorter life span and 
13
hence a lesser impact on climate change than the methane emissions - which if not 
14
effectively combusted has similar climate impacts as landfill emissions.  
However if AD captures the biogas and is used with CHP it is an example of a low carbon 
15
technology, which reduces greenhouse gases by offsetting emissions from other fossil 
16
fuelled power stations . Furthermore, AD as a waste disposal technique powers itself, for 
example studies on the treatment of sewage waste have suggested a 16% reduction in CO2 
17
emissions from using AD, in comparison to conventional sewage treatment techniques.   
Human Toxicity 
Human toxicity is a measure of the potential risk to health. Currently there is little data on 
health impacts from AD plants. Moreover these will differ (as with the impacts to climate) if 
the plant also provides CHP. The main emissions impacting humans are as follows: 
• Air emissions are low due to the enclosed nature of the process but if the biogas is 
combusted will include nitrogen oxides, which have been linked to lung problems and 
 4Anaerobic digestion 
18
allergies. However the emission rates using AD with CHP when compared to other 
19
forms of waste disposal are generally favourable.  
• Solid residue impacts from the digestate are more closely linked to the quality of 
feedstock. Metals such as mercury or lead will be higher in the digestates if the AD 
20
processes mixed residual waste rather than separated green and kitchen waste. 
Government control standards such as the Animal By-Products Regulation, will 
21
determine if it can be spread on the land and come into contact with humans. 
• Liquid emissions, similarly to solid emissions, depend on the feedstock. They are also 
subject to controls, determining whether they can be placed on the land and come into 
human contact.  
There are clear differences in health impacts depending on the type of input going into the 
AD plants, with properly separated biodegradable waste having lower health impacts than 
mixed waste. Generally AD, like composting, performs well compared with other types of 
waste disposal techniques. However, there are two important warnings attached to these 
conclusions. 
Firstly, types and levels of emissions will change according to the activities attached to AD. 
AD with CHP will emit sulphur dioxide, carbon dioxide and particulates; however these 
activities will produce net reductions in pollutant emissions compared to other energy 
sources such as coal fired power stations. 
Secondly, firm conclusions about human toxicity are difficult to draw due to the lack of 
operational AD plants and the true impacts of most emissions and the chemical interactions 
between them in the atmosphere are poorly understood. 
BOX 2 Case Study 
There is one example of a full scale anaerobic digestion plant in the UK but it is Europe 
that leads the way, with many more examples of AD as part of integrated waste 
management schemes found in Denmark and Germany.  
In the UK there is an integrated anaerobic digester within an MBT plant in Leicester, 
Wanlip, operated by Biffa. After a kerbside collection of recyclables, the remaining 
household waste is front-end sorted by a ball mill, at the main MBT plant. The resulting 
organic waste is hydrated and then processed in the AD plant. The whole process digests 
about 40,000 tonnes pa of organic waste which remains in the digester for around 18 
days. The biogas produced is converted by two turbines into electricity, which is then 
placed onto the national grid, with the waste water being re-circulated back into the 
digester and the remaining digestate then going to a windrow composting site before 
being applied to the land. Biffa have been unable to confirm whether the solid digestate 
will be used as a soil conditioner or go to landfill. 
A solution to the waste crisis? 
Anaerobic digestion is an important waste disposal option to consider, due to the speed and 
different types of green waste it processes and the by-products produced. Moreover it has 
 5Anaerobic digestion 
potential benefits as an energy source. Friends of the Earth would encourage local 
authorities to consider both AD and composting as part of a sustainable waste management 
system. Local conditions such as whether the area is urban or rural is likely to influence the 
process choice.  
Friends of the Earth also believes that AD should only be applied to the biological part of the 
waste stream and not unsorted residual waste, as the resulting digestate is unlikely to be 
suitable as a soil enhancer without further treatment. For this reason it is important for the 
segregation of the waste to take place at source, as this is a much more efficient way to 
22
separate biological waste than mechanical sorting systems. Not only will source separated 
waste collection systems increase the amount of waste recycled but it will also encourage 
people to take a greater responsibility for the waste they produce.
