   U.S. Builds Stockpile of Vaccine for Flu Pandemic

   Posted in United States, News, North America by Future Health Solutions - Spence on November 30th, 2005 

				
				
									U.S. Builds Stockpile of Vaccine for Flu Pandemic

U.S. Builds Stockpile of Vaccine for Flu Pandemic

By Justin Gillis

Washington Post Staff Writer

Wednesday, November 30, 2005; Page A01

The government expects to stockpile nearly 8 million doses of an experimental vaccine against pandemic influenza by February, and studies are underway that could stretch that supply to cover more than a third of the population, federal health experts said yesterday.

Two manufacturers are already making doses of the experimental vaccine under contract, and most of them will be delivered to government stockpiles by late December, according to presentations made to an advisory panel of the Health and Human Services Department.

That unusually rapid clip reflects the high priority the Bush administration has placed recently on preparing the nation for a catastrophic flu outbreak. The immediate plan is a start toward building a stockpile that eventually could reach tens of millions of doses, assuming that Congress appropriates enough money.In the worst case, scientists said, the vaccine being manufactured now would immunize only 4 million people, each of whom would need two shots a month apart. That means the vaccine would probably be restricted to critically needed personnel who would keep the government and public-safety services running during a pandemic. About a quarter of the vaccine is destined for a stockpile controlled by the Pentagon.

A pandemic would be expected to confine millions of people to their homes for weeks or months, shutting down much of the economy.

Techniques to dilute the vaccine while preserving a strong immune response are under study. In the most optimistic scenario, the stockpile due by February might be diluted to cover 120 million people out of a U.S. population of 298 million. Some preliminary research suggests that dilution will work, but scientists said larger studies are needed. How well the vaccine, diluted or not, would prevent influenza in a pandemic remains uncertain.

“I didn’t realize there was so much going on,” said Charles M. Helms, a University of Iowa doctor and chairman of the National Vaccine Advisory Committee, which heard reports on the government’s efforts at a meeting in Washington yesterday. “It’s incredible.”

William Hall, a spokesman for the Health and Human Services Department, said the government has made it a point not to claim that vaccine dilution would produce a huge stockpile in the short run, since the studies needed to prove that are still underway. “We’re trying to stretch the supply of vaccine, but to be perfectly honest, if a pandemic occurs tomorrow, we can cover 4 million people,” he said.

A fast-spreading form of influenza that sickens mostly birds but can also kill people has provoked worldwide alarm.

So far the virus cannot jump readily from person to person. But scores of people, mostly in Asia, have caught it from birds, and it has killed half of them. Authorities fear that the virus will evolve to the point that it can spread readily in the human population.

The influenza pandemic of 1918 killed perhaps 50 million people worldwide in months. President Bush announced a plan Nov. 1 to prepare the nation for a pandemic, and Congress is considering his request for more than $7 billion in emergency funds.

There is no licensed human vaccine today, and standard vaccine against annual flu would offer little protection. Several countries, including the United States, are rushing to develop and stockpile a vaccine. The government also is stockpiling Tamiflu, a drug that might be used to treat infected people, but for prevention, a vaccine is the preferred approach.

The effort is fraught with uncertainties, however. The experimental vaccine is designed to immunize people against the viral strain circulating in birds, but it is unclear how much protection it would provide if the virus evolved to spread readily among humans.

Multiple human tests are underway, and Linda C. Lambert, chief of respiratory diseases at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said researchers would offer some results soon. But scientists do not expect hard data on the number of deaths the vaccine could prevent to be available until a pandemic outbreak.

Sanofi Pasteur SA of Lyon, France, and Chiron Corp. of Emeryville, Calif., are making the experimental vaccine under government contract. Several companies are working on more advanced vaccines that might offer strong protection with one shot, but those are years away.

									 China denies bird flu cover-up                  

  				

					 					


   2 hours,  16 minutes ago 



 BEIJING (AFP) - China said there was no        SARS-like cover-up surrounding bird flu and said the nation was "capable" of stopping the deadly disease from spreading easily among humans. 

 Health Minister Gao Qiang said there would be no repeat of the 2003 scenario in which local governments did not openly report accurate figures about the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) until months after the outbreaks.

  "There’s no such covering up of bird flu transmissions in China," Gao told reporters at a news briefing.

  "Once there is an outbreak, we will inform the public immediately and tell the public to be more prepared."

  The SARS epidemic eventually spread to several countries, killing more than 800 people, including including 349 in China.

 Gao said authorities in China, the world’s most populous nation, would be able to prevent the disease from spreading easily among humans.

  "We have the determination and the capability to control the large scale spread of bird flu to humans," he said.

 Gao, however, acknowledged there were still weak links in the nation’s prevention system, saying the ability of health officials at local levels might not be high enough to detect cases in a timely manner.

 "I’m not worried about local governments hiding outbreaks, but I’m worried about our grassroots health and disease-prevention personnel not being able to find and confirm cases in a timely manner due to the low-level of competency and poor technical expertise," Gao said.

 "Because bird flu outbreaks are mostly in rural areas, some in remote mountainous areas, where local health conditions are rather poor and local staff are not very competent."

 It was crucial, then, for the health ministry to work closely with agriculture departments in local areas to step up training of medical staff there so they can identify and diagnose the disease quickly, Gao said.

  Gao also said the total number of outbreaks had reached 30 in China this year, affecting 11 provinces.

  The agriculture ministry announced Wednesday a 30th outbreak in Xinyuan county in the nation’s westernmost Xinjiang region.

 Some 300 farm raised birds died in the Biesituobie village on November 24, leading to the culling of some 1.18 million farm raised birds within a three kilometer (1.8 mile) radius of the village, the ministry said.

  The outbreak was confirmed as the H5N1 strain of bird flu on Wednesday, it said.

  China this month confirmed its first three human cases of bird flu, two of which were fatal.

 There was no change in the number of human cases Gao said, adding that none of the people who had contact with the three patients, including two who died, showed any symptoms.

 China is the biggest poultry producer in the world with 14 billion poultry farmed annually, and the fact 70 percent of the fowl are raised in backyard farms with close proximity to humans worries international health experts. 

   The lethal H5N1 strain of the bird flu virus has killed more than 60 people in Asia since 2003. 

Scientists warn that continued contact between infected birds and humans may eventually result in the virus mutating into a form that could be easily passed on by humans, sparking a pandemic that could kill millions. 

In related news, nine people have been arrested for selling fake bird flu vaccines that are suspected to have contributed to an outbreak of the disease in the northeastern province of Liaoning, state press said Wednesday. 

Police have arrested officials of the Jinyu Group, a company based in Inner Mongolia that produces medicines, and of the Inner Mongolian Biological Medical Products Factory, the Liaoxi Commercial Daily reported. 

After a 20-day investigation covering four provinces and regions, police found the two companies had manufactured and sold 200,000 vials of 12 different kinds of bird flu vaccine nationwide, the report said. 

China is seeking to vaccinate its billions of farm raised birds, but requires manufacturers to have a license to produce the vaccines. 

   Liaoning has been one of the worst hit areas in China.

									WHO: Culling wild birds ineffective against avian flu
  
 The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) today issued a media release that warned against culling wild birds in cities in countries affected by bird flu. WHO said this could distract attention from the campaign to contain the disease among poultry in the battle against the virus that could spark a potentially lethal human pandemic. 

 “This is unlikely to make any significant contribution to the protection of humans against avian influenza,” FAO senior officer responsible for infectious animal diseases Juan Lubroth said of reports that wild birds were being killed in Ho Chi Minh City in Viet Nam as a precautionary measure. 

 “There are other, much more important measures to be considered that deserve priority attention. Fighting the disease in poultry must remain the main focus of attention,” he added. “Wild bird species found in and around cities are different from the wetland waterfowl that have been identified as carriers of the avian influenza virus.” 

 The Agency has previously warned that the H5N1 strain that has hit several Asian countries is likely to be carried over long distances along the flyways of wild water birds to the Middle East, Europe, South Asia and Africa, with the potential to trigger a global human pandemic.

 “Controlling the virus in poultry is the most effective way by which the likelihood of the bird flu virus acquiring human-to-human transmissibility can be reduced,” Mr. Lubroth said.

 Ever since the first human case of H5N1, linked to widespread poultry outbreaks in Viet Nam and Thailand, was reported in January last year, UN health officials have warned that the virus could evolve into a human pandemic if it mutates into a form which could transmit easily between people. 

 The so-called Spanish flu pandemic of 1918-1920 is estimated to have killed from 20 million to 40 million people worldwide. Overall, there have been 132 reported human H5N1 cases, 68 of them fatal, all in South-East and East Asia. Some 150 million domestic birds have died or been culled in an effort to curb the spread.

 FAO, along with the UN World Health Organization (WHO) and the inter-governmental World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), has recommend a series of measures to fight the virus, including improved veterinary services, emergency preparedness plans, and control campaigns such as culling infected animals, vaccination and compensation for farmers to encourage them to report outbreaks.

DoD Helps Implement National Strategy for Pandemic Flu

 DoD Health Affairs

2005-11-30

The Department of Defense continues its partnership with other federal agencies to meet the objectives outlined last week in the President’s National Strategy for Pandemic Influenza. This strategy outlines how our nation will prepare, detect, and respond to a pandemic, whether it results from the strain currently in birds in Asia or another influenza virus.

Pandemic flu is a global outbreak of flu that occurs when a new flu virus appears in people, causes serious illness, and spreads easily from person to person. On average, pandemic flu occurs about every 30 to 40 years. The last pandemic flu occurred in 1968, and medical experts believe one may occur sometime in the near future. The avian flu strain H5N1 is the virus currently considered to be the most likely to cause a new flu pandemic. Scattered cases of H5N1 have occurred among people in direct contact with sick poultry or who ate undercooked poultry infected with the virus. So far, direct person-to-person spread of this virus has not been a problem.

We know that many of you are concerned about the avian flu and a possible pandemic. For that reason, we have created the Avian Flu Web page with frequently asked questions, glossary of important terms and health-related information.  The site includes other federal government links.  We will continue to add information as it becomes available.

What should I do now to protect myself and my family?  While seasonal flu vaccines do not protect against avian flu, getting vaccinated against seasonal flu is an important part of maintaining good body resistance and staying healthy overall. This is particularly important for high-risk groups (the very young, old, and those with chronic diseases) to decrease the overall risk of viral infection and possible complications. Use other personal protective measures such as frequent hand washing, covering coughs and staying home when sick.

In the past few months, DoD assistance to civil authorities during recent natural disasters has demonstrated that, when directed, we are able to respond with a wide array of capabilities to support the nation during times of need. With these same capabilities and others, we stand ready to assist in the event of a pandemic.

 Regulators cooperate in speeding bird flu vaccines                  

   				



By Maggie Fox, Health and Science Correspondent  Wed Nov 30, 4:50 PM ET

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - International regulators plan meetings early next year to agree on ways to speed the production of vaccine to fight a potential bird flu pandemic, a U.S. official said on Wednesday.

Fears about the H5N1 avian flu virus have accelerated the need for better global agreement on vaccines, but such a pact would also improve production of the annual influenza vaccine, said Dr. Jesse Goodman, director of the U.S.        Food and Drug Administration’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research.

Goodman said the FDA had become more active in helping companies get approval of flu vaccines.

“Our goal is to have vaccines that are safe and effective and to have them approved and available ahead of time,” he told a meeting of the U.S. National Vaccine Advisory Committee.

The H5N1 avian flu virus has infected 133 people in Asia since late 2003 and killed 68 of them. Several countries in the region are regularly reporting more suspected cases in people and outbreaks in poultry.

Annual flu kills about 250,000 people globally in an average year.

Scientists fear H5N1 could kill millions of people if it mutates into a form that passes easily among humans. The regular flu vaccine is useless against avian flu and there is no cure, although drugs can help reduce its severity.

Several companies are producing an experimental H5N1 vaccine, but hundreds of millions if not billions of doses would be needed if there were a pandemic. Flu vaccine production, now based on chicken eggs, is slow, unwieldy and uncertain.

Since flu viruses mutate so quickly, any vaccine made now would almost certainly provide poor protection against whatever strain eventually causes a pandemic, meaning a new vaccine would need to be formulated.

International officials have been warning for years about the dangers of influenza and the poor structures in place to defend against epidemics and pandemics.

The weaknesses were highlighted last year when British regulators took away Chiron Corp.’s license to make vaccine at its British plant — costing the United States nearly half its anticipated flu vaccine supply. The British move took the FDA by surprise.

NO SURPRISES

Officials do not want any such surprises if H5N1 or any other strain of influenza does cause a pandemic.

Goodman said the FDA had been in discussions with the        World Health Organization and other regulatory agencies about how to coordinate approval of a vaccine against H5N1 or some other strain of pandemic flu.

“Vaccine manufacturing is no longer a U.S. issue — it is a global problem,” Goodman said.

He said there were plans for two global regulatory meetings early next year, the first probably in Canada and a second in the United States. Issues would include what criteria are needed for approving new flu vaccines.

“The differences are not dramatic,” he said.

Another benefit would be global agreement on approval of the annual influenza vaccine, he said. Companies will only make pandemic flu vaccine if they can use the facilities to make annual flu vaccine, Goodman said.

“Nobody is going to produce 600 million doses every 50 years and then every 49 years something else,” he said.

“The ideal thing would to be perpetually prepared for a pandemic, not just this year when everybody happens to be really freaking out about it.”

The regulators may release written guidance on the criteria for approving a new vaccine, and Goodman said the FDA was making similar moves in one-on-one meetings with flu vaccine manufacturers.

“We have adapted to what I think are extraordinary circumstances through a number of extraordinary actions,” Goodman said.

Education International
BA Hons  Single, one year top-up
	

» HOW TO APPLY



How to apply

Apply directly to the University — contact our Admissions Office for an application form or download one from our website

Start date

September

Attendance

Full-time: 1 year

Campus and building

London North campus: Tower Building 

EU/international students

Read more on international students 

Open days/evenings

Dates and details of open days 

Entry requirements

You should have successfully completed a three-year teacher education certificate or diploma allowing you to teach in your home country and have some teaching experience with children aged 3—11. You should also be proficient at English at an academic level. If English is not your first language, you should have either IELTS 6 (with 5 in all components) or TOEFL 6000 (with TWE5) or CBT TOEFL 237 with at least 4 in essay writing. These requirements are varied in individual cases, including through AP(E)L

	

This course is for students who already have a Certificate or Diploma in education from overseas, as well as some teaching experience. It offers opportunities for further studies in relation to the early years and/or primary age range (3-11). 
Course structure

This course comprises five compulsory modules and three optional modules from either the BA (Hons) Education Studies or the BA (Hons) Early Childhood Studies courses.

While you should be proficient at writing in English, there are workshops, including group sessions and individual tuition, in 'English for Academic Purposes' to help you develop the different styles of writing required for academic and professional purposes.

You will also further develop your problem-solving, problem identification and analysis skills, typically through a project or equivalent.

Modules

	The Primary Curriculum and School Placement (two modules) 

	Project in Education (two modules) 

	Educational Issues in Primary/Early Years Education 


Placement

During the first semester, the course includes several day visits to a London primary school for observation and some teaching. During the second semester, you will spend further time in a school. This placement (across the two semesters) is a valuable opportunity for practical work experience.

IT training

You will have access to over 700 computers with a wide range of up-to-date software to provide the best possible environment for information and technology-based learning.

Teaching, learning and assessment

Assessment is predominantly through coursework.

Career opportunities

This course does not confer qualified teacher status, but allows you to consider teacher education in an international context, and many students progress to teaching courses or to further postgraduate study. If you are a UK resident, it may be a stepping-stone to a PGCE.

	 PEOPLE 	
	



	
	Edward Leigh MP
	
	 
      	Member of Parliament
                               for Gainsborough


			

	 ABOUT EDWARD	
	



	


    
	
			    
		    	

 
		    


		    
			
			
			
			
			     
			              	
              		
              	   

		    Edward was born in l950. He was educated at St Phillips School, London, the Oratory School Berkshire, the French Lycee, London and at Durham University (Modern History) where he was President of the Union Society.



He is the younger son of Sir Neville Leigh K.V.C.O., former clerk to the Privy Council. He is married with three daughters and three sons.



He is a barrister, and a member of the Inner Temple, practising for Goldsmiths Chambers in arbitration and criminal law.



            
	            

Edward's Experience



	            
				
				
				
				
				
	            Edward was a member of Richmond Borough Council and then the Greater London Council from l974 until l98l. 



He worked in the private office of Mrs Thatcher from l976-77 as private secretary in charge of her correspondence as Leader of the Opposition. 



Edward fought Teeside Middlesborough in the October l974 General Election. He was elected as Member of Parliament for Gainsborough & Horncastle in the June l983 General Election. He was Joint Secretary of the Conservative Parliamentary Defence Committee and the Parliamentary Agriculture Committee from 1983-85.



He was Chairman of the National Council for Civil Defence and was Director of the Coalition For Peace Through Security, until early 1985.



From 1990-1993, Edward was a Parliamentary Under Secretary of State, Department of Trade and Industry. Prior to that he was a Parliamentary Private Secretary in the Home Office.



In May 1997 he was elected Member of Parliament for the new seat of Gainsborough with a majority of 6,826.



He is currently a member of the Social Security Select Committee, and Joint Vice-Chairman of the Conservative Parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee. Edward has been the Chairman of the Public Accounts Select Committee since July 2001.

TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING, ENGLAND AND WALES


The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Amendment) Order 1998

The Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions, as respects England, and the Secretary of State for Wales, as respects Wales, in exercise of the powers conferred on them by sections 59, 60, 61(1) and 333(7) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990[1], and of all other powers enabling them in that behalf, hereby make the following Order:



Citation, commencement and interpretation

????

1.
?-?(1) This Order may be cited as the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Amendment) Order 1998, and shall come into force on 26th March 1998.


????(2) In this Order, any reference to Part 1, Part 24 or Part 25 is a reference to that numbered Part of Schedule 2 to the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 1995[2].



Changes to Part 1, Class H: The installation, alteration or replacement of a satellite antenna on a dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse

????

2.
In Class H of Part I?-?




(a) in paragraph H.1(a)(ii), omit "on or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse on article 1(4) land"; and


(b) omit paragraph H.1(a)(iii).




Changes to Part 24: Development by telecommunications code systems operators

????

3.
In Class A of Part 24?-?





(a) after paragraph 1(d), insert:




" 
(dd) in the case of the installation, alteration or replacement of apparatus (other than an antenna) on a mast, the height of the mast would, when the apparatus was installed, altered or replaced, exceed any relevant height limit specified in respect of apparatus in paragraphs A.1 (a), (b), (c) and (d), and for the purposes of applying the limit specified in sub-paragraph (c), the words "(taken by itself)" shall be omitted;"



(b) in paragraph 1(f)(iii), after "development", insert "(other than the installation, alteration or replacement of one small antenna)";


(c) in paragraph 1(g)(ii), after "development", insert "(other than the installation, alteration or replacement of a maximum of two small antennas)";


(d) in paragraph 1(h), after "in the case of development of any article 1(5) land", insert "(other than the installation, alteration or replacement of one small antenna on a dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse)";


(e) at the end of paragraph 1(k), omit the word "or";


(f) for paragraph 1(1), substitute:





" 
(l) in the case of the installation, alteration or replacement on a dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse of any telecommunications apparatus, that apparatus?-?




(i) is not a small antenna;


(ii) being a small antenna, would result in the presence on that dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of that dwellinghouse of more than one such antenna; or


(iii) being a small antenna, is to be located on a roof or on a chimney so that the highest part of the antenna would exceed in height the highest part of that roof or chimney respectively;";





(g) after paragraph 1(1), insert:





" 
(m) in the case of the installation, alteration or replacement on article 1(5) land of a small antenna on a dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse, the antenna is to be located?-?




(i) on a chimney;


(ii) on a building which exceeds 15 metres in height;


(iii) on a wall or roof slope which fronts a highway; or


(iv) in the Broads, on a wall or roof slope which fronts a waterway;



(n) in the case of the installation, alteration or replacement of a small antenna on a building which is not a dwellinghouse or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse?-?





(i) the building is on article 1(5) land;


(ii) the building is less than 15 metres in height, and the development would result in the presence on that building of more than one such antenna; or


(iii) the building is 15 metres or more in height, and the development would result in the presence on that building of more than two such antennas."; and





(h) in paragraph 3, after the definition of "relevant period", insert:








" 
"small antenna" means an antenna which?-?



(a) is for use in connection with a telephone system operating on a point to fixed multi-point basis;


(b) does not exceed 50 centimetres in any linear measurement; and


(c) does not, in two-dimensional profile, have an area exceeding 1,591 square centimetres;



and any calculation for the purposes of (b) and (c) shall exclude any feed element, reinforcing rim mountings and brackets."





Changes to Part 25: Other telecommunications development

????

4.
?-?(1) In Class A of Part 25, in paragraph A.1(d), for "90 centimetres", substitute "1.3 metres".


????(2) In Class B of Part 25, in paragraph 1(d):






(i) omit paragraphs (i) and (ii); and


(ii) after "exceed", insert "90 centimetres".








Signed by the authority of the Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions



Richard Caborn

Secretary of State for the Environment, Transport and the Regions



19th February 1998





Signed by authority of Secretary of State for Wales



Win Griffiths

Parliamentary Under Secretary of State, Welsh Office



26th February 1998






EXPLANATORY NOTE



(This note is not part of the Order)


This Order amends Parts 1, 24 and 25 of Schedule 2 to the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 1995 ("the 1995 Order"). Those Parts confer permitted development rights in respect of certain telecommunications development, including the erection of satellite antennas. Where such rights apply, no specific application for planning permission is needed.


Article 2 amends Part 1 of the 1995 Order (development within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse) as regards the size limit of a satellite antenna installed on or within the curtilage of a dwellinghouse (other than on a chimney) pursuant to permitted development rights. It applies throughout England and Wales a size limit for such an antenna of 90 centimetres (measured in any direction).


Article 3 amends Part 24 of the 1995 Order (development by telecommunications code system operators). It disapplies permitted development rights in respect of the installation, alteration or replacement of apparatus on a mast where the height of the mast would, as a result of that installation, alteration or replacement, be increased above specified limits. It modifies existing exclusions from such rights to permit in certain circumstances the installation, alteration or replacement of small antennas on a building. A small antenna is defined in article 3(h) as an antenna which is used in connection with a telephone system operating on a point to fixed multi-point basis, and which does not exceed 50 centimetres in any linear measurement or have an area exceeding 1,591 square centimetres.


Article 4 amends Part 25 of the 1995 Order (other telecommunications development) by raising the maximum size limit for satellite antennas on buildings or structures of a height of 15 metres or more to 1.3 metres.


Minor incidental and consequential changes are also made to the Parts mentioned.

title: Defra, UK - Environmental Protection - Recycling and Waste
text:
Defra, UK - Environmental Protection - Recycling and Waste 
Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs
 
The Producer Responsibility Regulations (Packaging Waste) Regulations 1997:
Recovery and Recycling Targets for Packaging Waste in 2001
(Regulatory Impact Assessment)
 




Purpose and intended effects of the measures


Issue and Objective


1.	The Producer Responsibility Obligations (Packaging Waste) Regulations 1997 No. 648 as amended in 1999 (1999 No. 1361 and 1999 No. 3447) were introduced to implement the EC Directive on packaging and packaging waste (94/62/EC) ("the Packaging Directive") in Great Britain. 


2.	The targets that appear in the 1997 Regulations were based on early and incomplete information about the tonnage of packaging in the waste stream and about the number of businesses obligated as well as those excluded. The experience accumulated since 1998 has allowed a better understanding of the total quantity of packaging in the waste stream and it has also provided data on the amount of packaging reported by obligated businesses.


3.	Consultation took place in 1998 on changing the targets for 1999, 2000 and 2001 but in announcing revised business targets for 1999 and 2000, the Minister kept open the possibility of changing the business targets for 2001 at a later date. 


4.	On the basis of the data reported from obligated businesses in 1999, the Government published in August 2000 a further Consultation Paper on Recovery and Recycling Targets for Packaging Waste in 2001 (Consultation Paper) proposing to raise UK business targets from 52% (recovery target) and 16% (material specific target) to 58% and 18%. On the basis on the data available at the time, 58% and 18% were the targets necessary to achieve the Packaging Directive targets of 50% and 15%.


5.	The Government completed a general review of the data used in the Consultation Paper in the light of the now available more recent data reported in 2000 from obligated businesses, revised estimates for total packaging in the waste stream from Materials Organisations (MOs) and responses to the Consultation Paper.


6.	As a result of this review the Government intends to raise the targets to 56% (recovery target) and 18% (material specific target). Such changes to the targets are now felt necessary in order to ensure that the current level of targets for 2001 in the Regulations are sufficient for the UK to meet its mandatory obligations under the EC Packaging Directive.


7.	This RIA has been prepared by considering the overall UK-wide costs of the proposed changes to the packaging regime as it is difficult to separate the cost directly applicable to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. However, the amending legislation to implement the changes is planned to be made by separate Regulations in Scotland and Northern Ireland from England and Wales. It would therefore be useful if a separate assessment of Scottish and Northern Ireland cost implications can be made, although without further information, the best estimate is that costs in Scotland will be of the order of 10% of the UK total and that costs in Northern Ireland will be in the order of 2.5% of the UK total.


Risk Assessment


8.	The targets need to be increased in order to achieve the UK's mandatory targets set in the Packaging Directive. Failure to meet the targets could potentially result in infraction proceedings against the UK which may result in a judgement from the European Court of Justice and possibly the imposition of financial penalties on the UK. 


9.	Further risks associated with not meeting the current targets set in the Packaging Directive include the extra environmental disamenity generated by the landfilling of packaging waste that could be recovered. 


Options


Identify the Options


10.	Two options have been identified after the review of all the data in the Consultation Paper issued in August 2000 and after the consideration of the results of consultancy work.



	Option 1 – Keep the planned recovery/recycling targets for 2001
	Option 2 – Change the planned recovery/recycling targets for 2001




For the purposes of this RIA, Option 1 (the status quo) is the counterfactual. Option 2 will be assessed relative to this baseline.


Option 1


11.	Targets for 2001 are left at the current level of 52% overall recovery and within this 16% for each specific material by recycling (except for wood and other).


Option 2


12.	Targets are increased to a level necessary to ensure compliance with the Packaging Directive, namely 56% overall recovery and 18% for each specific material by recycling (except for wood and other).


Issues of Equity and Fairness


13.	Option 2 will impact across all obligated companies. The impact on each sector will be proportional to the sectoral split of obligations already set in the Regulations. In addition, the material specific recycling target will have a varying impact on different materials sectors given the current differences in recycling levels of each material. There will be no burden on small businesses as the Regulations already include safeguards for smaller businesses. (See section "Impact on Small Businesses" at the end)


14.	However it should be noted that a trade-off exists between avoiding extra burdens on smaller businesses and the proportional burden placed on obligated businesses (i.e. businesses above the thresholds). Targets apply to all the packaging waste in the waste stream, therefore, the more exclusions there are to protect smaller businesses and others, such as charities, the higher the burden on obligated businesses to recover and recycle the required percentage of packaging waste.


Benefits


Identify the benefits


Option 1


15.	Obligated businesses will not be affected further than the current Regulations require. Their costs and planning efforts on how to meet their recovery obligation for packaging waste in 2001 will not increase more than was expected in 1997.


Option 2


16.	The benefits of option 2 are:



	to ensure that the legally binding targets set in the Packaging Directive are met, ensuring that the adverse legal and public opinion consequences of failing to meet the EU mandatory recovery/recycling targets are avoided;
	to further reduce the impact on the environment of packaging waste; to provide an higher level of environmental protection.




Quantifying and valuing the benefits


Option 1


17.	This is the baseline scenario against which the benefits of option 2 will be assessed. This option will deliver a total recovery of about 4,413,000t of waste packaging in 2001. This will deliver 47.4% recovery of packaging waste. This would fall below the legally binding target of 50% in the Packaging Directive and some material specific targets as laid down in the Packaging Directive would not be met.


Option 2


18.	Potential infraction proceedings together with a possible eventual penalty from the ECJ for non-compliance with the Packaging Directive will be avoided assuming that obligated businesses meet the revised targets. The benefit of avoiding this is hard to quantify but the ECJ could potentially impose daily financial penalties based on the UK's GDP. Adverse public opinion for not meeting EU mandatory recycling targets for packaging waste will also be avoided. The benefit of avoiding this is hard to quantify. It Is difficult to value the environmental benefits of a reduction of the environmental impact of packaging waste. Environmental benefits could result from a reduction in the amounts of waste going to landfill whilst the production of recyclate might mitigate against the use of virgin materials. Hence  the greater recovery and recycling of option 2, (compared to option 1) could potentially reduce emissions to air, soil and water. This is an objective that underlies the UK's vision of sustainable development.


19.	This option is expected to deliver a total recovery of about 4,750,000t of waste packaging in 2001. This is expected to deliver 51.0% recovery of packaging waste which, after taking into account the uncertainty in estimates (including the possibility that some tonnages reported by the smaller businesses may go down in 2001), will ensure that the legally binding target of 50% in the Packaging Directive is met and that all material specific targets as laid down in the Packaging Directive are met.


Compliance costs for business, charities and voluntary organisations


Business sectors affected


20.	The only sectors that will be affected by this proposal are those already obligated under the Regulations and those carrying out recovery and recycling of packaging waste. The sectors obligated under the Regulations are:





	Manufacturing packaging raw materials




	Converting materials into packaging




	Using packaging to pack or wrap products




	Selling packaging to the final consumers




	Importing packaging materials, packaging or packaged goods.






In total, the Regulations place an obligation on approximately 14,000 firms. In addition, businesses which carry out recovery and recycling of packaging waste will be affected. In total there are approximately 210 such businesses.



Compliance costs for a "typical" business


21.	Charities as defined in Section 506 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988 are exempt from the Regulations. De-minimus businesses (those below the threshold limits of £2 million turnover and 50 tonnes of packaging handled) will also not face any compliance costs, as they are not affected by the Regulations. 


Option 1


22.	Option 1 will not result in compliance costs in addition to those anticipated in 1997 under the current Regulations. Estimated costs are around £11,000 per business on average.  (This is obtained by dividing the number of businesses estimated to be obligated (14,000) for the total cost of compliance of Option 1 (£155,000,000))


23.	However, smaller obligated businesses and larger obligated businesses are likely to experience a lower or higher cost respectively as a result of the smaller or larger number of packaging tonnes handled respectively.


Option 2


24.	It is difficult to estimate the compliance costs for a typical business as this varies enormously according to the type of business (manufacturer, converter, packer-filler and distributor) and the total tonnage of packaging handled. On a per firm basis, option 2 (see below) will imply an "average" increase of about 8.5% in the cost of compliance with the Regulations. This has been calculated by estimating an 'average' compliance cost.


25.	Dividing the estimated additional cost under this option by the number of estimated obligated firms (14,000) gives average total compliance cost of £930 per firm.


26.	However, smaller obligated businesses and larger obligated businesses are likely to experience a lower or higher cost respectively as a result of the smaller or larger number of packaging tonnes handled respectively. Furthermore, businesses that use different materials may incur different costs.


27.	Furthermore, some businesses and compliance schemes may be aware that targets are likely to increase in 2001 if the UK is to meet its legally binding targets under the Packaging Directive. Therefore, it is possible that businesses and compliance schemes will be able to reduce their future costs by planning in advance to meet higher targets.


Total Compliance costs


Option 1


28.	There are legal and public opinion consequences of not meeting the mandatory EU targets. In the extreme this would amount to a daily fine payable until the situation has been rectified. The total cost of recycling and recovery under option 1 is estimated to be £155,000,000 (excluding any fines imposed by the ECJ). There is some uncertainty surrounding these costs; assumptions and calculations underling this estimates are presented in Appendix A.


Option 2


29.	The total cost of complying with option 2 is estimated to be £168,000,000. There is some uncertainty surrounding these costs; assumptions and calculations underling this estimate are presented in Appendix A. Thus the cost to firms of complying with option 2 is £ 13,000,000 more than the cost of complying with option 1.


Consultation with small businesses: 'The Litmus Test'


30.	Businesses that do not simultaneously satisfy the two thresholds of the Regulations (i.e. businesses with an annual turnover of £2m or less; and those handling 50t or less of packaging per annum) are excluded from the obligation to recover and recycle waste packaging.  Therefore the proposed changes to the level of targets do not affect small businesses below this threshold.


Other costs


31.	As the reporting and recycling obligations are already in place, apart from some one-off adjustment costs, there are no other costs of compliance to businesses due to proposed changes in the level of recovery/recycling targets.


Result of Consultation


32.	Responses to the Consultation Paper on Recovery and Recycling Targets for Packaging Waste in 2001 have been carefully analysed. They have highlighted few imprecision in the Consultation Paper and they have informed our revision of the data and estimates presented in the paper itself.


33.	There were 171 responses to the consultation. These included individual businesses, trade associations (e.g. British Retail Consortium, Food and Drink Federation, Brewers and Licensed Retailers Association); and compliance schemes.  With few exceptions, all responses oppose the proposed target of 58% recovery. There were a limited number of themes which were mentioned by most of those responding.  The main themes are -



	last-minute increase is unfair to those who have complied so far;
	increase only needed because the Agency has not deterred free-riders; those complying should not have to compensate for non-compliers;
	lower turnover threshold test to £1million;
	insufficient infrastructure to cope with the required increaset;
	not enough time to meet a 58% target.




34.	A number of responses comment on the fact that there has been insufficient investment in the recycling infrastructure, yet some £110 million has been paid for PRNs in 1998 and 1999 alone. We will be asking the Advisory Committee to focus as a priority on the reprocessing infrastructure.


35.	A number of responses suggest reverting to a £1million turnover threshold.  Industry thinks this will bring in a lot more businesses but it would also bring in relatively small amounts of packaging, could increase compliance costs and would require a significantly greater monitoring effort on the part of the Agencies.


Appendix A


Estimating the cost to firms of complying with options 1& 2


36.	In order to estimate the total cost to business of compliance with both options 1 and 2, it is assumed that the cost of recycling one tonne of material is equal to the average price of a PRN for that material. Furthermore it is assumed that non-material specific recycling for 2001 is distributed across different materials according to the percentage split of 1999. To calculate the difference in costs between option 1 and option 2 one can assess the costs assuming PRN prices remain the same under both options (i.e. assuming that raising to 56% and 18% instead of 52% and 16% the targets does not raise the price of PRNs). To this can then be added the resulting costs should PRN prices be higher under option 2 than under option 1.


Costs assuming no difference in the PRN prices between the two options


37.	The following needs to be estimated:


a)	the average price of PRNs in 2001;

b)	the percentage split of non-specific recycling across different materials in 2001.


a)	the likely average price of PRNs in 2001


38.	The average of price of a PRN in 1998 has been used to estimate an average price of a PRN in 2001. (Such assumption is considered more appropriate than using or including the average price for 1999 as 1999 prices were generally lower than the 1998 prices, and higher prices are expected for 2001. PRN prices are expected to rise as targets rise from the 2000 level (45% recovery, 13% material specific recycling). The estimated prices are used for both option 1 and option 2. However, due to more stringent targets, PRN prices may rise higher under option two, this factor is estimated in section "Cost assuming difference in the PRN prices between the two options)  The average (1998) prices used in order to estimate the price of a PRN in 2001 were £112/t for plastic, £21/t for aluminium, £32/t for paper, £22/t for glass and £30/t for steel. Economic theory suggests the price of wood recovery and mixed (incineration) PRNs will be the same. The average (1998) price of an incineration PRN is £31; this price will also be used for wood. The price of £31/t will also be applied to "other" materials. These estimate prices are based on average prices for PRNs paid by one compliance scheme during 1998.


b)	the percentage split of non-specific recycling across different materials in 2001


39.	The percentage split for non-specific material recycling in 2001 is assumed to be equal to the 1999 percentage splits as 2000 data for recycling achievements will not be available till early 2001. In 1999, these were: 70.75% for paper, 17% for glass, 6.67% for steel, 3.87% for wood, 1.56% for plastic, and 0.15% for aluminium).


Estimated cost of OPTION 1


40.	Based on a total for packaging in the waste stream in 2001 of 9,313,900 (as from latest Materials Organisations' estimates) and assuming a split between obligated and non obligated businesses equal to 91,1% and 8,9% respectively, under option 1 the total recovery of packaging waste is estimated to be 4,412,594t. The total recycling (material specific and non-specific material recycling) of packaging waste for 2001 is estimated at 3,887,594 tonnes. In particular at least 544,250t is estimated to be paper; 333,642t is estimated to be glass; 18,277t is estimated to be aluminium; 107,361t is estimated to be steel; 253,408t is estimated to be plastic; 95,148t is estimated to be wood; 5,635t is estimated to be "other" and 2,529,873t is estimated to be non-specified material recycling. Packaging recovery from energy from waste is estimated at 525,000t. 


41.	The recycling of non-specified material has been allocated across different materials according to the percentage split estimated in b).


42.	Based on the estimates calculated in a) and b), the total cost of option 1 is estimated to be about £155,000,000.


Estimated cost of OPTION 2


43.	Based on a total for packaging in the waste stream in 2001 of 9,313,900 (as from latest Materials Organisations' estimates) and assuming a split between obligated and non obligated businesses equal to 91,1% and 8,9% respectively, under option 2 the total recovery of packaging waste is estimated to be 4,752,024t. The total recycling (material specific and non-specific material recycling) of packaging waste for 2001 is estimated at 4,227,024 tonnes. In particular at least 612,281t is estimated to be paper; 375,347t is estimated to be glass; 20,561t is estimated to be aluminium; 120,782t is estimated to be steel; 285,085t is estimated to be plastic; 107,042t is estimated to be wood; 6,339t is estimated to be "other" and 2,699,588t is estimated to be non-specified material recycling. Packaging recovery from energy from waste is estimated at 525,000t. 


44.	The recycling of non-specified material has been allocated across different materials according to the percentage split estimated in b).


45.	Based on the estimates calculated in a) and b), the total cost of option 2 is estimated to be £168,000,000.


46.	The differential cost between option 1 and option 2 is therefore estimated as £13,000,000.


Costs assuming difference in the PRN prices between the two options


47.	Although the estimates used for PRN prices (i.e. average prices for 1998) are considerably higher than current market prices in order to allow for increase in prices related to increase in targets, it is possible that PRN prices rise more in Option 2 than Option 1.


48.	Calculating the likely change as a result of raising the targets would be an extremely complicated task and involve considerable uncertainty. Thus, for the purposes of this RIA, the figures should be seen as illustrative.


49.	For each £1 increase from the average PRN prices in 1998 for each materials estimated in a) (see 28.), the cost of option 2 relative to option 1 will rise by about £4,752,000.


Total cost difference between the two options


50.	The differential cost between option 1 and option 2 is therefore estimated as £13,000,000 plus £4,752,000 per £1 increase in PRN prices from 1998 average prices for all materials between the two options. Hence:



	if PRN prices did not rise above 1998 average the estimated differential cost would be £13,000,000;
	if PRN prices rose by an additional £1 on average for all materials in option 2 the estimated differential cost would be £17,752,000;
	if PRN prices rose by an additional £5 on average for all materials in option 2 the estimated differential cost would be £35,860,000.
